title: Understand the Function
text: We have the function $$f(x)=3\sqrt{x-2}$$. Look at the expression inside the square root: $$x-2$$. This will help us find the domain.

title: Recognize the Square Root
text: The square root function, $$\sqrt{x}$$, only works for non-negative numbers (0 or positive values). This is because the square root of a negative number is not a real number.

title: What Must be True?
text: Since we know $$\sqrt{x-2}$$ needs to work, $$x-2$$ must be at least $$0$$. Set up an inequality: $$x-2 \geq 0$$ to find when it will work.

title: Solve the Inequality
text: Add $$2$$ to both sides of the inequality $$x-2 \geq 0$$. What does $$x$$ need to be?

title: The Domain in Interval Notation
text: Interval notation uses brackets and parentheses to describe all the possible x-values (domain) of the function. Square brackets, [ or ], mean the endpoint is included. Parentheses, ( or ), mean the endpoint is not included. Your answer from the last step gives the lower limit.
